unit_learning_outcomes.description: Extend your acquired knowledge of neuroanatomy to discuss, evaluate and interpret clinical case studies and published research.

Describe in detail the organisation, structure and interconnected function of the nervous system, including the cerebral cortex, brainstem, diencephalon, cerebellum, basal ganglia, limbic system, spinal cord, cranial and spinal nerves. This includes demonstrated knowledge of the meninges, ventricular system, blood supply and main histological features of the tissues.

Trace somatic and autonomic sensory inputs (from receptor to cortex, via brainstem and thalamus) and motor outputs (from motor cortex to effector organ, including the inputs from the basal ganglia and cerebellum). This includes outlining the specific ascending and descending pathways, and the pathways for taste, smell, hearing, balance, and vision
Show an appreciation and respect for those who have bequeathed their bodies to research
Show that you are competent in analysing, interpreting and assessing relevant anatomical structures on images, photographs, bones, models, prosections, normal radiographs, MRI and CT scans.
Relate your structural knowledge of the nervous system to its embryological development.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: readings assigned on a weekly basis for tutorials and practicals

assessments.description: 10 minute quizzes held at the start of tutorials.
Practical examination assessing knowledge of the nervous system by identifying structures on models, prosections, images, bones, radiographs, MRI and CT images. A written examination.

assessments.assessment_title: Presentation of a neuroscience media alert
assessments.description: Group presentation of a science/medical media alert that relates to neuroanatomy, or a pathology/disease associated with the nervous system.

This will cover the content of the entire semester. It tests knowledge of the theory, and the ability to connect that knowledge to real life situations (e.g. case studies). It will consist of a 2 hour written exam with multiple choice questions and short answer questions.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances, North Ryde
data.description: This unit builds on the basic anatomy taught in ANAT1001. It focuses on the structure and function of the nervous system. The unit utilises an integrated approach within which relevant gross anatomy, histology and embryology, as well as clinical and applied anatomy are incorporated.
data.title: Neuroanatomy

description: This unit builds on the basic anatomy taught in ANAT1001. It focuses on the structure and function of the nervous system. The unit utilises an integrated approach within which relevant gross anatomy, histology and embryology, as well as clinical and applied anatomy are incorporated.
title: Neuroanatomy
